Build ID: M20070718-0800

When working with bundles that need to import various JDK packages (such as crypto, net, xml...) the compiler reports an error:

  "No available bundle exports package 'javax.crypto'"

These pacakges are supposed to be provided by the JDK.

From the equinox mailing list thread "No available bundle exports package 'javax.swing.event'" this looked like a PDE->UI bug.  David, are you getting errors when compiling your project in your workspace or when you attempt to export it from your workspace?  If you are getting "red X's" in your workspace then this bug should be moved to PDE->UI

Do you define a Bundle-ReqiuredExecutionEnvironment header in your bundle?

I found what the problem was for my javax.crypto issue:

The project had been imported from an ANT buildfile (File > New > Project > Java >  Java Project from existing ANT build file). By doing so, in its 
Project properties > Java Build Path > Libraries, it had specified "JRE_LIB/rt.jar" as the class path.

I found that JRE_LIB is deprecated, and the "JRE System Library" should be used instead. By doing that, it picked up the jce.jar in addition to the rt.jar, and voila javax.crypto became visible.

So my problem might have been a different one than the originally reported one from the mailing list, which named javax.swing.event (which is defined in rt.jar) -- As Tom said, you should be checking whether you have a Manifest.mf specifying a Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment.

I'm wondering whether I should file a separate bug against JDT, saying that Import from Ant should not use JRE_LIB but rather the JRE System Library.

Based on the comment below from Thomas, I am changing this from PDE->Build to PDE->UI.

I am indeed getting the "red X's" in my workspace, in the Manifest file beside the imports.

Indeed, javax.crypto as well as the javax.swing.* packages are all problematic in my case. When I'm back in the office tomorrow I'll add the complete list that is causing me problems (may not be exhaustive in terms of this problem).

There is no Bundle-ReqiuredExecutionEnvironment header defined in my bundle manifest.

Here is a longer list of the packages that are not properly imported:

 javax.crypto
 javax.crypto.spec
 javax.imageio
 javax.imageio.stream
 javax.swing.event
 javax.swing.text
 javax.swing.tree
 javax.xml.transform
 javax.xml.transform.stream

Also:

 org.xml.sax
 org.xml.sax.helpers

As an additional note: I am able to run my application, so what happens at runtime at the error seen in the UI are very separate.

Just wondering about the status of this, as the problem persists.

Is any more information required to reproduce?

Thank you.
If you have the project that contains the problem and can attach it to the bug report, that would be great.  We can start with that and see if we can reproduce the problem.

David, I tried your test project and only see missing package references sun.misc and sun.reflect.  Are you still seeing others after you add Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.5?

Tom, if a user tries to import sun.misc (or sun.reflect) from the BREE for J2SE 1.5, should they have access to that package.  I went and looked up the J2SE-1.5.profile shipped in org.eclipse.osgi and saw that the org.osgi.framework.system.packages property did not contain either one of these packages.  I figured if the package is not specified in org.osgi.framework.system.packages then the resolver does not know the package is coming from the VM, right?  

If this is the case, this is the expected behavior.  Then the next question is, do we add it to the .profile file?  Should PDE be doing something differently?

(In reply to comment #18)
> Tom, if a user tries to import sun.misc (or sun.reflect) from the BREE for J2SE
> 1.5, should they have access to that package.  

No, these packages are not part of the standard for J2SE 1.5.  They are sun specific packages.

> I went and looked up the
> J2SE-1.5.profile shipped in org.eclipse.osgi and saw that the
> org.osgi.framework.system.packages property did not contain either one of these
> packages.  I figured if the package is not specified in
> org.osgi.framework.system.packages then the resolver does not know the package
> is coming from the VM, right?  

Correct.

> 
> If this is the case, this is the expected behavior.  Then the next question is,
> do we add it to the .profile file?  Should PDE be doing something differently?
> 

We should not add the VM specific packages to the standard profiles in org.eclipse.osgi.  These are meant to represent standard Execution Environment profiles, not vendor specific VMs.  PDE should not promote using packages which are vm specific.

One option could be to allow developers to specify their own profiles for the VMs they have installed and use that for both launching and for populating the platform properties in the PDE State.  I consider that a corner case though and not something that many developers should do.

Sorry, the addition of the sun.* packages was an error on my part. They shouldn't be there...
